examples.title:
System
  modal appears the moment an app first calls CoreLocation.
  Offers “Allow Once”, “Allow While Using App”, “Don’t Allow”, plus map
  preview.
examples.use_case:
Mobile
  apps requesting fine‑grained or approximate GPS data.
examples.why_selected:
Gold‑standard
  OS‑level just‑in‑time prompt with granular and time‑bounded choices.
examples.pbd_alignment:
Proactive, Privacy
  as default, End‑to‑End security
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
User
  control & freedom; Visibility of system status

examples.title:
Full‑screen
  dialog triggered only on first sensitive API call; “Allow only while using”,
  “Ask every time”, “Don’t allow”.
examples.use_case:
Android
  apps requesting camera, microphone, storage, etc.
examples.why_selected:
Illustrates
  contextual consent deferred until feature use, reducing habituation.
examples.pbd_alignment:
Privacy
  embedded, Respect for user privacy
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Recognition
  rather than recall; Minimalist design

examples.title:
URL‑bar
  chip with mini‑icon and dropdown (“Allow / Block”) triggered when a web app
  calls getUserMedia().
examples.use_case:
Web apps
  seeking mic input (e.g., video conferencing).
examples.why_selected:
Lightweight,
  non‑modal banner respects browsing flow while ensuring explicit consent.

examples.title:
OS‑integrated
  prompt appears when user taps “Discover People”; offers continue without
  contacts.
examples.use_case:
Social
  networking apps encouraging friend discovery while respecting privacy.
examples.why_selected:
Good
  example of app‑triggered, feature‑gated data request.

examples.title:
Browser‑level
  infobar with “Share Location / Don’t Share / Always
  Share” plus site‑info icon to revoke later.
examples.use_case:
Privacy‑centric
  browser reinforcing transparency for websites.
examples.why_selected:
Showcases
  revocable, per‑site decision history aligning with user expectations.
examples.pbd_alignment:
Visibility
  & transparency, Respect for user privacy
